general: This law changes how much money people get when they retire from working in government jobs like being a judge or a teacher. It also makes sure that some people who used to work for banks that got taken over by the government can still get a good pension. And it decides how long judges should keep working after they retire.

series.short: Remediable Service Definition Under Public Service Pensions and Judicial Offices Act 2022
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section defines "remediable service" for the purposes of Chapter 1 of the Public Service Pensions and Judicial Offices Act 2022.
* Simplified point 2: Remediable service is any continuous period of service in an employment or office that meets certain conditions, including that the service takes place between April 1, 2012, and March 31, 2022, and that the person was in service on March 31, 2012, or earlier.
* Simplified point 3: The conditions for remediable service also include that the person was in service in an employment or office that is pensionable service under a Chapter 1 legacy scheme, a judicial legacy scheme, or a local government legacy scheme, and that there is no "disqualifying gap in service" (a period longer than 5 years without service in an employment or office that is pensionable service under one of these schemes).
* Simplified point 4: The section also defines "the closing date" as March 31, 2015, for service that is pensionable service under a Chapter 1 scheme that is not an Agency scheme, and March 31, 2016, for service that is pensionable service under an Agency scheme.
* Simplified point 5: The section includes provisions for determining whether service is pensionable service under a particular scheme, and for treating service as pensionable service under certain schemes despite the service not being pensionable service under a Chapter 1 scheme or excess teacher service.

series.short: "UK Government's Power to Pay Compensation for Non-Discrimination Breaches in Public Service Pension Schemes"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government has the power to pay compensation to members of public service pension schemes who have incurred losses due to breaches of non-discrimination rules.
* Simplified point 2: The scheme manager for a Chapter 1 legacy scheme may pay amounts by way of compensation in respect of compensatable losses incurred by members or, in the case of deceased members, their personal representatives.
* Simplified point 3: Compensatable losses include losses attributable to a relevant breach of a non-discrimination rule, the application of any provision of, or made under, this Chapter, or the value of rights in respect of remediable service which would, apart from section 2(1), be pensionable service under a Chapter 1 new scheme.
* Simplified point 4: The power to pay compensation is subject to certain conditions and limitations, such as the member being a relevant member, the loss being a Part 4 tax loss, and the scheme manager being satisfied that it is more likely than not that the member would have entered into the same or similar arrangements but for a relevant breach of a non-discrimination rule.
* Simplified point 5: The scheme regulations for a Chapter 1 legacy scheme may make provision for indirect compensation, where a member has incurred a compensatable loss that is a Part 4 tax loss, and the member is instead paid such additional benefits under the scheme as may be determined in accordance with the regulations.
* Simplified point 6: The scheme regulations for a Chapter 1 legacy scheme may also make provision for remedial arrangements to pay voluntary contributions to the legacy schemes, and for the reduction of liabilities to pay voluntary contributions by tax relief amounts.

series.short: Remedying Discrimination in Employment: Putting Things Back to Normal
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section of the legislation applies to cases where an "immediate detriment remedy" has been obtained in relation to a person's remediable service in an employment or office.

* Simplified point 3: The provision that may be made under the section includes provision corresponding to any provision of sections 2 to 30, or provision applying any provision of this Chapter in its application to persons of a description specified in the regulations, with or without modifications.

series.short: Remediable Service Under Local Government Schemes: Definition and Conditions
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section defines "remediable service" for the purposes of Chapter 1 of the Public Service Pensions and Judicial Offices Act 2022.
* Simplified point 2: Remediable service is any continuous period of service in an employment or office that meets four conditions:
	+ The service must take place between the day after the closing date (March 31, 2014 or March 31, 2015, depending on the scheme) and March 31, 2022 or the date the person reaches legacy scheme normal pension age.
	+ The service must be pensionable service under a local government new scheme.
	+ The person must have been in pensionable service under a Chapter 1 legacy scheme, a judicial legacy scheme, or a local government legacy scheme on March 31, 2012 or any earlier day.
	+ There must be no disqualifying gap in service falling within the period.
* Simplified point 3: A "disqualifying gap in service" is a period longer than five years during which the person is not in service in an employment or office that is pensionable service under a local government scheme.
* Simplified point 4: The "closing date" refers to March 31, 2014 for service that is pensionable service under regulations under section 7 of the Superannuation Act 1972 that relate to persons in England and Wales, or March 31, 2015 for service that is pensionable service under any other local government new scheme.
* Simplified point 5: "Legacy scheme normal pension age" refers to the person's normal pension age under the relevant legacy scheme, or age 65 if there is no such normal pension age.
